creator: deepa.kethe@flytxt.com
text:
We are using the Jmeter for performance testing.
The throughput response time for 2 consumers is 1.8/min  and for 1000 consumers 
it is 1.2/sec which is wrong 

And also could you please suggest what setting shoudl i change so that the 
throughput response time  is always /sec

Why is it wrong? How long did the test last, and how many requests were 
processed?

As to always showing the throughput response RATE in seconds - that needs a 
code change: please create a Bugzilla enhancement request.
creator: sebb@apache.org
deepa.kethe@flytxt.com
text:
(In reply to comment #1)
> Why is it wrong? How long did the test last, and how many requests were 
> processed?
> As to always showing the throughput response RATE in seconds - that needs a 
> code change: please create a Bugzilla enhancement request.


Hi thanks for the reply.I have found the problem .It always calculated for the 
number of samples that are run.Can u suggest me a method where it can make the 
samples number as 0(zero).As of now i have to open the testplan each time so 
that i can see how long does it take to run just one sample of an API call
I have run api call for one consumer thread with loop count as 1

creator: sebb@apache.org
text:
(In reply to comment #2)
> (In reply to comment #1)
> > Why is it wrong? How long did the test last, and how many requests were 
> > processed?
> > As to always showing the throughput response RATE in seconds - that needs 
a 
> > code change: please create a Bugzilla enhancement request.
> Hi thanks for the reply.I have found the problem .It always calculated for 
the 
> number of samples that are run.Can u suggest me a method where it can make 
the 
> samples number as 0(zero).

You can use Run / Clear All to clear out any old samples, if that is what you 
mean.
Thanks a lot .I will fire off the API calls and let you know abt the result
creator: deepa.kethe@flytxt.com
sebb@apache.org
text: Original problem was a misunderstanding of the way it works
